item.description:
I listened to Derek Thompson’s podcast with Atlantic editor Yoni Appelbaum on his upcoming book Stuck: How the Privileged and the Propertied Broke the Engine of American Opportunity. The discussion was fascinating: positing that the decline in American mobility is the most important social change in the last fifty years 1 and that it’s the fault of the progressive movement.

I found it fascinating to learn how high mobility was in the past and in particular about “moving day” as a day where all of the leases 2 came up and everyone moved all at once while Europeans came over and spectated . Apparently it still happens in Quebec; I should go gawk or maybe market my enthusiastic if slightly clumsy moving skills.

I'm Taylor and I'm a statistics nerd.

I'm currently working at YouTube as a Staff Research Data Scientist. Prior to that I worked in search ads.

I went to school at Carnegie Mellon where I worked on conditional density estimation. I adapted random forests, neural networks, and nearest neighbors to esitmate conditional densities for applications in multimodal prediction and Approximate Bayesian Computation.

Prior to that I was indoctrinated in Bayesian Statistics at Duke for my undergrad.

item.title: Non-Transitive Bradley Terry Models
item.description:
One thing that has always bugged me about Bradley Terry models is that it doesn’t model rock-paper-scissors.

To recap the Bradley Terry model posits that each entity has a strength \(\gamma_{i}\) and when competing the probability of victory for entity a over entity b is

\[exp(\gamma_{a}) / exp(\gamma_{a}) + exp(\gamma_{b})\]

or to make it clearer logit(γa - γb).
